bibl.title: Letter from Charles [Caverico] to Howard A. Kelly, May 23, 1910

div1.p: [Caverico] compliments Kelly on his book, "Walter Reed and Yellow Fever."

div1.head: Letter from Charles [Caverico] to Howard A. Kelly, May 23, 1910
div1.opener:
1
Lombard Du Page Co. Illinois5-23-10
Professor Howard A. Kelly M. D.
Medical Dept. Johns Hopkins University
Baltimore Maryland.
Dear Sir
div1.p:
I am a Congregational Minister
not exactly “in good and regular standing-”
sitting rather, for I am “retired” superannuated"
and of course “supernumerary”.

Sometime [?] two or three years past
a friend of mine (perhaps of yours also for
he has been a student in your dept of
your University) Emmel H. PomeroyM.D.
for many years in hospital work connected
with the Calumet Mines Mich, but now
in such work at Black Mountain Lee Co.
Va. gave me a copy of a book entitled
“Walter Reed and Yellow Fever.”

A year or two passed before I attempted
to read it. The reason of this delay was
that during this time I was not “all together,”
Within a few days past I took up the
book and read it from A. to Z & read
the “Bibliography” at the close.

I have acknowledged to Dr. Pomeroy my
indebtedness for the book.

It occurs to me that I have not quite
done duty in the matter.

I am under obligation to you for writing
the book. I have marked on the page
next the cover “Valuable and Interesting.”
I am trying to pay my debts in these
my latter days and I want at least to
recognize a debt due to you.

I owe you thanks for the introductions
you have given me to the gentlemen
of whom you have within.

It makes one think better of humanity
when you see such illustrations of
what the race may be. They make “life
worth living” for the rest of us.

Thank you for the introduction to them.
There I owe you much for the science
you have set before me - especially
the science of the medical profession.
Really I see the greatness of that
profession as I have not before.
I spent ten years at law before I went
into the ministry so I have some
3
idea of the wealth of those two
professions.

But you now make me reverence the
medical profession as I have not
before. You have opened a range-
a vista into its [?] and
possibilities till I am
“Lost in wonder love and praise”
of that profession.

Then finally I owe you much for
your excellent English. You have
excellent mastery this. Even in
technical matters you have the happy
art that reveals so that “the way-faring
man” though the customary “fool”
“need not err therein.”

There is one more point I must mention-
- your great hearted entrance into
the life of those to whom you have
given me introduction. You have
held than in honor and affection
or you could not have aroused
those sentiments in the heart of a
reader.
div1.closer:
Most Cordially Yours Charles Caverico.
4
P. S.
In looking at your name I think
I cannot err in putting you down
as a Cousin Kelt.
I am in the 5th generation from
Ireland - the name being originally
the common Kavanagh.
The form in which I write it came
to me from my ancestors who lived
in a town settled by Caverlys--
a case of re expelling by attraction.
I once asked a captain of a military
company in [?] Wis., his name.
He said Kelly. Yet he was a blonde
Norwegian- a testimony I suppose
of migration from Ireland to Norway
in some former days.
C. C.
Do not answer this letter. Its purpose is
accomplished in its writing. You have
enough to do else.
